Oh, a little correction here :) It doesn't matter will the networks 
be CTR=
NNs or regular ANNs. The substrate is just a group of points. 
It depends o=
n the application how the connections/parameters will be 
evolved and used.=
 And the GUI will not be limited to just 3D. 
Perhaps I'm too drunk right n=
ow. :) Good night. 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" 
<peta=
r_chervenski@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> 
> If I begin writing this GUI (I will, =
but my job is taking a lot of 
my 
> time right now), it will be mostly 3D =
and targeted for the Win32 
> platform. The node placement schemes can be i=
mplemented in a 
similar 
> way as vector graphics is. Ken, I will do some =
study on these 
> algorithms. 
> 
> I already have a substrate class, capab=
le of generating a parralel 
> (layered, like most drawings of backprop net=
s), circular and a 
matrix-
> like layers of nodes in 3D, given the node co=
unts for each layer. 
> I'll add spherical, cubic and perhaps even random s=
uch schemes. 
> 
> I like the idea of taking apart the substrate from the C=
PPN-NEAT 
> stuff. They are no similar things at all. It sucks to have your=
 
> experimental application generate the substrate in some algorithmic 
> =
way. 
> There should be a stand-alone app that deals with substrates, and 
=
> another one that runs the evolution and is experiment-specific. 
This 
> =
is more flexible. 
> 
> I am currently running experiments with leaky-integ=
rator networks, 
> the CPPNs have 3 outputs and when the biases and time co=
nstants are 
> computed, the (x1, y1, 1.0) are used only (others are set to=
 0.0). 
> This was a suggestion that Ken told me, and I want to thank him f=
or 
> this, because I see this is the right way to evolve node properties 
=
> along with connections with the same connective CPPN :) 
> 
> So the GUI =
I am planning will possibly include CTRNN substrates as 
> well. 
> 
> As s=
oon as I have it working, I will send the application & source 
in 
> the f=
iles section. I appreciate any help with this from our 
> community. 
> 
> =
Peter
>

ptation) to n-dimensional cubes (and with a little more effort
